lines.text: Radish so red / Radish so red / Plucked from the heart of your warm little bed / Sprinkle some salt on the top of your head /
[eats radish]
Delicious.
[after watching a sound effects recording session for a cartoon train]
How did you like it?
Oh, fine, fine. Only after all, wouldn't it be a lot easier just to wreck a real train?

Sweet little upside-down cake / Cares and woes, you've got'em / Poor little upside-down cake / Your top is on your bottom / Alas, little upside-down cake / Your troubles never stop / Because, little upside-down cake / Your bottom's on your top.
You've got to be mad to breathe fire, but I'm not mad at anybody.
But try real hard. Concentrate.
[the dragon tries, but all he can muster is a puny smoke ring]
Not very good, is it?
Nope. Too bad you're not a real dragon, instead of a punk poet.

[Angry]
"Punk poet"?
[Now fire is coming out of his mouth]
Ooh, say that again.
Punk poet.
Again.
Punk poet.
Again.
Punk poet.

[Delighted]
Ooh, I'm mad! I'm mad! I'm mad!
Punk poet! Punk poet! Punk poet!
Very good. I like the way you handle that fowl language.

[as Donald Duck]
Foul language? Why the very idea!
Uh, the time has come, you know.

[clapping excitedly]
You mean... I die now?
Oh yes indeed. As per-agreed, we'll seal our pact, old thing.
[placing the lance under the Dragon's arm]
Take that!
[first lines]

[Reading]
"So they set off up the hill, arm in arm, the knight, the dragon, and the boy. The lights in the little village began to go out one by one."
[Is interrupted by a toy rifle going off]
"But there were stars and a late moon as they climbed the downs together."
[Toy rifle again]
Robert, please.
[Pan to Robert Benchley lying on a raft in the pool, with the toy rifle]
Go on, I can hear in any position.
[Shoots a dart at a duck decoy in the pool]

[Continues reading]
"And as they turned the last corner and disappeared from view, snatches of an old song were borne back on the night breeze. I can't be certain which of them was singing, but I think it was the dragon."
Go on, I'm listening.
That was the end, and a very lovely end, too.
Yeah, charming, charming. It's funny. No matter which way I aim, I always hit the same duck.
Robert, I have a wonderful idea. We'll sell this book to Walt Disney.
Well, you can't. It belongs to your nephew.
[Looks at rifle]
So does this, too. I wonder what he'd take for it.
I mean the idea, for a movie. I'm sure if you went to his studio and suggested it to him, he'd jump at it.
Me suggest a story to Walt Disney? Why, I hardly know him.
Well, you hardly knew me when you suggested marriage.
Yeah, look at the trouble I got into. He can't listen to every crackpot with a wild idea.
You might be the exception. All you would have to do would be to go to his studio and show him the book.
I wouldn't dream of it!
They're always open to new ideas. Get your things on, and stop shilly-shallying.

[Stands up on raft]
I am not shillying and I am not shallying. But once and for all, I will not go to the studio. I will not make myself look ridiculous.
[Falls through]

[Bubbles come out of his mouth]
And that's final.

[Holding up a cel of Bambi in front of her]
Like it?
I'd be all right if you could get that reindeer out of the way.
I'll see if I can scare up the background that goes with it.
Nothing wrong with the one I just saw.

[a man hands her a painting]
Thanks. This is his background. He fits right on top of it, like this. There.
And very cunning, too. I'd like to take him home with me.
[Bambi suddenly comes to life and hides behind a rock in the background]
What do you know? He took me seriously.
You're a quiet little fellow, aren't you?
Well, there really isn't much to talk about.
He talks!
Why? Is it against the rules?
Oh, Doctor!
[Faints]
Yes, the horse, the servant of mankind, the aristocrat of the animal kingdom. Noble, faithful, obedient, and kind, most magnificent of all dumb animals
Dumb?
Sir Giles, I presume?
Come, come, come, come, lad. Stop mumbling.
I came to talk about the dragon.
Ah, yes, yes, yes. Another tale of woe and misery, I suppose. Devoured your flocks, no doubt.
Oh, no, sir. He...
Aha! Made off with your loving parents, has he? Well, they shall be avenged!
But you don't understand...
What? Don't tell me he's kidnapped some fair damsel, with flaxen hair, and ruby lips, and form divine? Why, he can't do that to her! He shall pay dearly on the field of battle.
But that's just it. He won't fight.
Yes. He... He won't fight? Preposterous! The fellow must be an infernal cad. Bit of a rotter, what?
He is not. He's a nice old dragon who likes to write poetry.
Poetry?
Yes. You know, verses?
How jolly! Ha ha! I'm a bit of a bard myself, you know.
You a poet, too?
Yes. No doubt you've heard of my Ode to a Fleecy Cloud?
Well, I...
Oh fleecy cloud, O cloud of fleece, up in the sky so high... Oh. Oh, my.
Oh, my.
[Benchley is watching a camera man shooting cels of Donald Duck]
Yeah, but he still doesn't move.
Just a minute, big boy. Give me time, give me time!
[Benchley laughs in astonishment]
Look, I'll show ya. I'll show ya. Now look. First my foot is up here, see?
Uh-huh.
Then, it's down here, understand?
Now I get it.
Like this...
Yeah.
And this...
I see.
And that. See?
Sure.
When I do it faster, I'm walking. Get it?
Yeah, certainly.
Do you mind if I recite a poem?
You, boy? Why, well, oh, not at all!
Oh, of course, of course. Rather, rather!
'Tis evening / From the stars above / A soft mysterious light / Brings thoughts of friendship, joy and love.
[shouts]
Now how 'bout that fight?
Oh, son, I seen it! Up on the bounds it was, all covered with scales and such, and a tail with a sort of hook on it! Now wait until I catch me breath. It's horrible! That's what it is, horrible!
It's only a dragon, father.
Oh... Only a dragon? Oh! The village! Help! There's a dragon a-coming! Help!
Don't worry, father. I'll have a look at him.

[about Donald Duck; chuckling]
He kills me. Only I can't understand a thing he says.
[last lines]

So while you were shilly-shallying, they made the picture. I never knew it to fail. In all the years that I've known you, you've always been too late. Really, Robert, I can't understand why you're forever letting these opportunities slip through your fingers. Anyone would've thought of it in time, months ago. But you...
[sighs]
Well, why don't you say something?

[as Donald Duck]
Aw, phooey!
[quacking furiously]
Phooey!
[Robert Benchley and his wife are driving to the Disney studio]
It's a wild goose chase, that's what it is. I don't imagine he's out here in the first place.
Where else would he be?
You know these movie producers; New York, Saratoga, Palm Beach...
Hollywood.
Well, that's splendid!

[Goofy has fallen off his horse]
When you've fallen from a horse, lie quietly. Remember, a horse will never step on a fallen rider.
[the horse jumps on Goofy's back]
Have you had any nice battles lately?
Battles? Oh, no, no, no battles. No.
Oh. Oh, probably too busy scourging the countryside and devouring fair damsels, then.
Scourging? Devouring? Good heavens, no.
But don't you ever do anything desperate?
Well, yes, I... I do make up poetry.
Poetry?
Verses, you know? Care to hear my latest sonnet?
Well, I...
Oh, you'll love this. I call it, "Just A-Drifting".
[sings]
Just a-drifting o'er the leaves/Like a dewdrop, fancy free,/Playing with the gentle breezes,/Romping with the bumble beezes./Oh, what fun! Joy never ceases,/Just a-drifting.
No truer has ever been uttered than those of Confucius, or some other philosopher, who said, "The outside of a horse is good for the inside of a man."
